title: Shares in C&C Properties rise more than 8 per cent as tycoon Nick Candy considers takeover bid
text:
Shares in Capital & Counties Properties rose more than 8 per cent after property tycoon Nick Candy said he was considering a takeover bid.

Candy, 46, confirmed he is leading a consortium of interested bidders who are pondering a 'possible cash offer' for the developer, which owns Earls Court and Covent Garden in London.

But Capital said 'there has been no approach' from Candy and that it was already in exclusive talks with real-estate business Delancey about the possible sale of Earls Court.

Before Candy's announcement, Capital was valued at about £2.1 billion but shares yesterday rose by 8.3 per cent, or 20.7p, to 270.5p, pushing it up to more than £2.3 billion.

Candy (pictured with his wife, actress Holly Valance) is reportedly in contact with Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund over the potential deal, and would make a bid through his firm Candy Ventures. But he said there 'can be no certainty' one will be made.

Capital has seen its share value cut almost in half over the past four years, although shares have been on the rise in recent weeks on the back of the takeover interest.
